Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
Postdoctoral Fellow: Emily Lescak

Proposal number: 1611913

This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2016, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow to increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Dr. Emily Lescak is "Effects of Chronic Exposure to Low Levels of Antibiotics on Development of Threespine Stickleback Fish." The host institution for this fellowship is the University of Alaska Anchorage, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Milligan-Myhre.

The goal of this project is to study short- and long-term effects of chronic exposure to low levels of antibiotics on microbial community diversity and host development in a genetically variable fish species, threespine stickleback (Gasterosteus aculeatus), a model organism for understanding the impact of environmental contaminants on vertebrate physiology. Vertebrate host/microbe interactions are crucial for nutrient absorption, somatic growth, and immune system development. Disruptions to the microbiota, such as those caused by antibiotics, can therefore have both immediate and long-term effects on host physiology. Low levels of more than a dozen types of antibiotics have been detected in waterways in the United States and Europe. However, little is known about how chronic exposure impacts host-microbe interactions in aquatic vertebrates, like fish, or how host genetic background influences the response of the microbiota to disruption. The Fellow is testing the hypotheses that 1) the levels of antibiotics found in the environment are sufficient to disrupt microbial community composition, which will result in changes to timing of organ development, growth, behavior, and inflammatory state, and 2) that there will be individualized responses to antibiotic exposure due to differences in host genetic background. The Fellow is rearing stickleback from two genetically distinct populations at low levels of antibiotics and in a control (untreated water). Microbial diversity, inflammatory state, and physiological and behavioral development are being compared at a series of key developmental time points until reproductive maturity is reached. Results will help elucidate how gut microbial communities respond to chronic disturbances, how critical aspects of vertebrate physiology may be disrupted by antibiotic exposure in the environment, and how host genetic background influences susceptibility to short- and long-term changes in microbial diversity and development.

In terms of training, the Fellow is 1) learning new techniques in bioinformatics, histology, and microbiology; 2) developing immune response assays; 3) mentoring students. The Fellow is giving presentations on her research and career training to K-12 students in Anchorage, Alaska. Furthermore, she is training high school students through the Anchorage School District's mentorship program and identifying undergraduate and graduate trainees through the Alaska Native Science and Engineering Program and BUILD EXITO. By establishing the University of Alaska Anchorage's first postdoctoral association, the Fellow is organizing professional development for postdoctoral fellows and graduate students. Thus, the Fellow is engaging trainees of all levels from diverse backgrounds in research important to ecosystem health.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on the effects of exposure to germ-free conditions as well as common aquatic contaminants (antibiotics, fluridone, and perchlorate) on gut microbial community diversity along with physiological and behavioral development in threespine stickleback fish (Gasterosteus aculeatus), a model organism for understanding the impact of environmental contaminants on vertebrate development. The fellow found differences in physiology and behavior in juvenile stickleback from genetically-distinct populations exposed to germ-free environments and antibiotics, suggesting that microbiota disturbance can cause developmental perturbations. Interestingly, there were inter-population differences in the magnitude and direction of responses, suggesting that some populations were more vulnerable to developmental instabiility than others. In vivo experiments revealed 10 strains of bacteria isolated from stickleback guts that experienced changes in growth rate in the presence of environmentally-relevant levels of perchlorate. This finding prompted a follow-up in vivo study to examine response of microbial communities to perchlorate exposure. These results are in preparation. Differences were found in microbial diversity in adult stickleback exposed to 150ppb concentrations of fluridone and methanol (the solvent for fluridone) as compared to 9ppb concentrations and control conditions, suggesting that exposure to this herbicide has potential to disrupt gut microbial communities. Additionally, we found differences in community composition in individuals infected with Schistocephalus parasites, suggesting that these parasites may have widespread negative effects on host health. This research lays the groundwork for questions focused on the relative contributions of genetics and environment on microbial community and short- and long-term consequences of exposure to clinical levels of antibiotics and other environmental contaminants at key developmental windows.

Exposure to environmentally relevant concentrations of endocrine-disrupting chemicals and antidepressants influences behavior and development in wildlife. Environmental impacts of persistent low levels of antibiotics in aquatic environments are largely unknown, but they also have great potential to influence a wide variety of biotic processes. The health of aquatic ecosystems is largely dependent upon the maintenance of host-microbiota symbioses, but these delicate relationships can be disrupted by anthropogenic environmental perturbations. The proposed work sheds light on how host genetic background influences microbial community composition, development, and immune response and how these critical aspects of host physiology are disrupted by exposure to environmentally-relevant concentrations of aquatic contaminants. It will also increase our understanding of whether a population’s response to microbial disturbance is indicative of its resilience to environmental perturbations, and has potential to drive changes in the way waste water is treated prior to release into aquatic environments inhabited by fish.

Much of the fellow's outreach was focused on Alaska Native students. She taught workshops for the University of Alaska Anchorage's (UAA) Alaska Native Science and Engineering Program, which brings students from around the state to the university to participate in science and engineering activities. She presented to high school classes in Anchorage and mentored high school and undergraduate students. She established UAA’s first postdoctoral association, which provided professional development opportunities for students and postdocs.
